awd_titl_txt: NRT: A training incubator for addressing urban environmental change from Ridge to Reef (R2R)
awd_abstract_narration:
Urban and suburban areas, particularly in southern California, face multiple environmental challenges such as wildfires, pollution, and sea level rise. To address these challenges successfully will require strong partnerships that cross academic and government agency boundaries and that engage all stakeholders. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to the University of California, Irvine, will establish the Ridge-to-Reef (R2R) training model for community-engaged graduate training through partnerships with government agencies, non-governmental organizations, and the private sector. The primary goal of R2R is to train the next generation of professionals with the skills required to translate conceptual knowledge into practical environmental solutions in urban landscapes.  R2R anticipates training forty-five (45) PhD or Master's students, including twenty-five (25) funded trainees from ecology, engineering, and earth system science programs. 

This graduate research training program will foster a skilled workforce to tackle relevant problems facing urban environments.  The R2R training program will actively engage with government agencies, non-governmental organizations, and the private sector to develop research questions and methods so that outcomes align with real-world problems. A Research in Action Internship (RAIN) program will provide students with hands-on skills training guided by the partners and academic faculty. The R2R curriculum will focus on interdisciplinary knowledge, communication skills, and professional development. A summer institute will teach data analysis skills, and an environmental solutions practicum will require trainees to apply their knowledge to real-world problems and datasets. Trainees who complete program requirements and an internship will receive a Certificate in Urban Ecosystem Management to facilitate career placement. Research products and curriculum materials will be disseminated to enrich graduate programs outside UC Irvine. By training the next generation of environmental problem solvers, R2R will enhance the sustainable management of urban ecosystems. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through comprehensive traineeship models that are innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

por.por_cntn:
Environmental challenges, from regional to global, have become increasingly complex and require broader solutions than a singular discipline can provide. Although there is growing need for interdisciplinary research and team science, most graduate education programs in the United States still train students within the confines of a particular discipline or specialty. The Ridge 2 Reef program at the University of California, Irvine, aimed to provide transferable and interdisciplinary skills training to over 50 graduate students from multiple fields to better prepare the next generation of environmental problem solvers. The program was successful in its goals because it fostered a ‘culture of improvement’ that solicited regular feedback from students and responded quickly to reflect trainees’ needs across all levels of program management. Due to trainee input and program leaders’ dedication to the culture of improvement, there was a complete curriculum overhaul during the first two years of the program, resulting in a final structure that was more successful and consistent in achieving educational goals related to technical skills, career development, building partnerships, and supporting participants from underrepresented backgrounds. Evaluation results from biannual trainee surveys suggest that the flexibility of program leaders (the culture of improvement), diversity of training offered (overhauled courses), and opportunities for partnership boosted the confidence, competence, and preparation of graduate students pursuing environmental career paths. This success was reflected by an average improvement of 14.8% in communication skills, 27.8% in career knowledge, and 28.8% in trainees’ knowledge and understanding of global perspectives of research. The structure and evolution of the Ridge 2 Reef program provides an example for other graduate education programs to better incorporate interdisciplinary training and student feedback, ultimately improving graduate education and contributing to more robustly trained career scientists.
